You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: It had been decided that the machine must go. I didn"t find myself agreeing with Major Milic very much these days. His methods were harsh, brutal and he had become a fanatic. I"d call him more of a terrorist than a freedom fighter. But he was right, the machine had to go. I didn"t have any confidence we could do it, however.


The resistance had changed in the last couple years. The Emperor"s personal secret project was brought online. Though it was round, it wasn"t like it the "Death Star." This Empire was real, and it made smarter decisions. It spent its time and money on a brain. CyCLOPS- Cybernetic, Control, Law-enforcement, and Online Policing System- changed the rules of human nature more and more every day. It make it possible for a few people to effectively watch the entire human populace at once. It watched, it learned, it analyzed, it predicted, and it remembered with perfect clarity all at a single time.

I had been surprised at first when Major Milic rescued me from my prison, but not when I figured out what he planned to do. He needed me for two reasons. One- I could fly helicopters, the old ones without autopilot. Two- I knew where CyCLOPS was. And I suppose a third reason too; I would never turn him into the Imperial Union.

I agreed to help, not that I had a lot of choice when everything I knew was lost and there was a gun in my face. I left the prison behind, but all the while knowing I would die with them instead.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

CyCLOPS is not easy to get near. It was secret to begin with, but they knew better than to rely on that alone. Through torture, Major Milic"s loyal team discovered a lot information about the facility. Though most work with it is done remotely, it has over 500 that work directly with the machine on-site. These are mostly fat technicians and overpaid civilians, not that Milic recognized civilians anymore. They wouldn"t put up much of a fight when push came to shove.

The security came from a reinforced, mixed-guard company made up of Sentinels and Assault Forces. One company of three platoons. Each platoon covered a 12-hour shift. One was on days, one on nights, one on recovery cycle at all times. They had six guard towers with heavy machine guns on the walled perimeter. The walls were made of carbonized concrete, the gate was heavy metal and automatic, and there was electrified razor wire across the top. Four roving patrols covered the exterior of the facility, rejecting any trespassers onto the "Navajo Sanctuary Reservation." At least one large armored vehicle was ready at all times for a quick reaction force. The rest of the on-shift platoon patrolled the inside of the compound and checked key points.

If at any point the guards caught wind of our approach and intentions, the other platoons would be woken and activated as reserves. An entire company of heavily armed and armored Sentinels would be vastly too much to deal with, and we"d be slaughtered. We had to 1- approach undetected, 2- blind the guard towers so they could not shoot down our helicopters, 3- secure the barracks and take the reserves hostage before they could get to their arms room, 4- deal with the existing guards in the compound, 5- lock the gate to prevent the roving patrols from returning with more firepower, 6- break into and make our way into the facility, and at last, 7- blow CyCLOPS to high hell. None of the major processor banks can survive. No one knows the extent of its capabilities for certain, besides the Emperor and his chosen team, but it may likely begin to back up its data to external servers outside of the facility. The more we can destroy, the more we"ve set back the Empire, and the more time we've bought for a larger resistance to mobilize.

They are dependent on the machine now. They will be weaker than they were before it"s installation. But first, we had to get there. And I had a bad feeling. So many things could go wrong.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

I listened as intently as I could to Milic"s briefing. He"d thought of everything. Even from his little bunker hidden away from the world, he"d managed to gather a lot of intelligence. From his position at the top of the map, he could point out every section of the base, where we would land, where the satellite communications were, where the barracks and arms rooms were, where we would enter the facility, and more. I wasn"t sure how he knew all of this. I think I didn"t want to know.

"Sam, are you fuckin" paying attention!?" His eyes seemed to glow from the light reflected off the map in the otherwise dark bunker.

"What? Yes. I know where to land." Truthfully I"d never been the same since that prison. I couldn"t focus on anything too long.

"But after that?"

"What... what am I doing after that? That wasn"t... I didn"t agree to-"

"I don"t give a shit. You"re with me. I"m not letting you out of my sight."

"Who"s going to stay with the helicopter?"

"Jacob will keep it running." He pointed to Powell, next to me. Anyone who knew him called him Powell. Only people who pretended to know him called him Jake or Jacob. They"d had a long history, but that told me how close they weren"t. Powell"s eyes locked with mine for a moment then looked away. He was a hostage here, too. He was the man that taught me to fly. He was old now. So was I.

"I"m not shooting anyone."

"That"s fine. You"ll help carry explosives. You"ve got no problem blowing this thing up. That"s what we agreed on, right?"

"Okay... right. I"m with you."

"You"re attached to my hip. You go where I fuckin" tell you and nowhere else. Is that understood?"

"I"m with you." I growled.

"3rd squad, alpha-team"s goals are the communications array..." he continued. But again, I already wasn"t listening. A faint whining grew in my ears, and I faded out into one of my blackout spells. After coming all this way, and everything I"ve worked for- everything I did to fight the Empire- it was probably Milic that was going to kill me.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

During pre-flight checks with Powell, we talked a little bit. It was nice. I climbed up on top of the back of the bird to give the yoke a good look.

"This piece of shit is not gonna fly." I interjected, looked at the rust near the blade hub.

"It"ll fly. I flew it yesterday."

"The rotors are going to fall off before we get there."

"No... but we"re in for a bumpy ride. She definitely handles like a... heh heh, Sammy, you remember that old two-seater we flew up to that Appalachian relay station?"

"Oh dear god, we almost died. On three separate occasions." I grinned.

"We"ve been through tougher spots." Powell grinned too and climbed up the other side. His entire bald head wrinkled when he smiled.

"Yeah... but we were younger men. And the Empire didn"t rule the world yet."

"Nothing lasts forever. Not youth, and not this crummy empire. They all fall down eventually. We"re just giving it a good shove."

"You really think we"re going to win?" my grin faded. That old feeling returned.

"I think so. Major Milic"s got his plan down tight. He"s resourced everything he needs. We have our opening. You don"t think we can?"

The yoke, despite several conditions I would normally reject, appeared okay. The blades were in surprisingly good condition. It would fly all the way to the scene of the crash. "I don"t think so."

"You need to give the guy more credit. I know you don"t agree with his methods, but he"s a warrior. This is what he was built for. You have that prison mindset still. The walls are all closed in around you."

"Oh I don"t think it"s the prison that got to me," I looked out into the setting sun of the evening. The scenery from up here was incredible.

"Is this about Lindsey?"

"No. Lindsey"s gone. This is about us. Now. Though I admit, it"s hard to forget her face with a bullet in it. I"m glad she"s not here to see this. This is going to be... a mess."

Powell reached up and grabbed my hand and held it in both of his. "You"ve gotta have a little faith in this team. They know what they"re doing."

"I know. But this team never met the Emperor. I"ve met him, and... No one on earth knows what they"re doing compared to him. He sees everything coming."

"Sam, you have to believe we can win."

"I know... there"s a chance we can win. But we need to be ready. If it"s not a trap now, it will be by the time we get there." The sun slipped from view, and we were left standing in the dark."

In the fading light, Powell and I finished our checks, the weight of what lay ahead settling over us like a shroud. The helicopter, despite its age and wear, was our chariot into the heart of the beast. I could only hope it would hold together long enough to get us there and, if we were lucky, back out again.

The night of the operation arrived, cloaked in a moonless darkness that seemed to mirror the void in my heart. Major Milic gathered the team for a final briefing. His eyes were wild, almost feverish, as he went over the plan one last time. I could see the fanaticism burning within him, a fire that threatened to consume us all.

"Remember, stealth is key," Milic growled. "We approach from the east, using the mountains as cover. The helicopters will land here and here." He pointed to two spots on the map, his finger stabbing the paper like a dagger. "From there, we split into our assigned teams. Alpha will take out the guard towers. Bravo will secure the barracks. Charlie, you're with me. We'll breach the facility and place the charges."

I glanced at Powell, who gave me a nod of reassurance. I wished I could share his optimism, but the dread in my gut was a writhing, living thing. I knew the Emperor too well. He was always three steps ahead, his mind a labyrinth of contingencies and countermeasures.

The helicopters roared to life, their blades slicing through the night air with a deafening whir. I took the controls of the lead bird, Powell by my side. The rest of the team was crammed into the back, their faces a mix of determination and fear. We lifted off, the ground falling away beneath us as we climbed into the inky blackness.

The flight was tense and silent, save for the thrum of the rotors and the occasional crackle of static from the radio. I kept us low, skimming the treetops to avoid detection. The facility loomed ahead, a monolith of steel and concrete rising from the desert like a cancerous growth.

As we approached the landing zone, I felt a prickling sensation on the back of my neck. Something was off. I scanned the horizon, my eyes straining against the darkness. Then I saw it—a faint glimmer of light, a reflection where there shouldn't have been one.

"Milic," I barked into the radio, "we've got company. Ten o'clock, ground level."

Milic's voice came back, harsh and immediate. "Take evasive action. All teams, prepare for contact."

I banked hard, the helicopter groaning in protest as I pushed it to its limits. The ground erupted beneath us, a hail of gunfire tearing through the night. They were waiting for us. The Emperor had known we were coming.

"Abort!" I shouted, but it was too late. The second helicopter, caught in the crossfire, spiraled out of control and crashed into the desert floor in a ball of flame. I could hear the screams of the dying over the radio, a chorus of agony that would haunt me forever.

Powell and I exchanged a grim look. We were committed now, trapped in a dance of death with the Empire. I set the helicopter down hard, the landing gear crumpling beneath us as we hit the ground. The team spilled out, returning fire as they sought cover.

Milic was at my side, his face contorted with rage. "We push forward," he snarled. "We finish the mission."

I grabbed his arm, pulling him back as a burst of gunfire kicked up dust at our feet. "Milic, it's a trap. We have to fall back, regroup—"

He shook me off, his eyes wild. "No! We end this tonight. With me, Sam. Now!"

I hesitated, the chaos of the battle raging around me. Then I saw Powell, pinned down behind a rock, his leg a bloody mess. He looked at me, his eyes pleading. I couldn't leave him. Not again.

"I'm sorry, Milic," I said, my voice barely audible over the din of battle. "I can't follow you this time."

I broke away, sprinting towards Powell. Bullets whizzed past me, the air thick with the scent of cordite and death. I reached Powell, dragging him back towards the helicopter. He screamed in pain, but I couldn't stop. We had to get out of there.

The helicopter was a wreck, but it was our only chance. I hauled Powell into the back, then climbed into the pilot's seat. The engine coughed and sputtered, but it caught, the rotors slowly beginning to turn.

As we lifted off, I saw Milic, a lone figure charging towards the facility, his team scattered and broken around him. He was a dead man, but he didn't care. He was consumed by his obsession, his need to destroy the machine.

I turned the helicopter away, the battle receding into the distance. I didn't know where we were going, only that we had to get away. The mission was a failure, the resistance shattered. But Powell and I were alive, and that had to count for something.

As we flew into the night, I couldn't shake the feeling that this wasn't over. The Emperor was still out there, his machine still watching, still learning. But for now, all I could do was fly, carrying the remnants of hope with me into the darkness.

[Story]: My name is Kristin Renee Saunders, and my life has become crazy in a big fucking way. And the shit part is I can't even tell anyone about it. Forget talking to my therapist, she'd have me locked up and the key thrown away if I attempted to unload any of my problems and experiences. After all, who would believe anyone who said they were involved in a murderous power-grab between witches, vampires, werewolves and other supernatural races?


Not one damn person, that's who.

But if I don't get this off my chest, I might lock me up and throw away the key. If only not to get killed by something that doesn't have a box next to it on a coroner's report.

It all started a few months back, while I was waiting tables at the Whistle Stop. The Whistle is a small little restaurant in Glendale, Kentucky that serves up the best southern dishes and desserts in the area. Folks travel everywhere from Louisville to out of state, and I've even served folks from as far away as Cali and Alaska. We have many regulars, but it's not uncommon to see strange folks here, even if Glendale is literally a one-stop-sign kinda place.

The two women at table ten made me strangely uneasy from the beginning, requesting a table as far away from any of the others as possible. When Hailey, the hostess, sat them at table ten , I felt an inside groan. Table ten- the haunted table. Not that anyone had actually seen a ghost, but unexplainable things always seem to happen there. Drinks will unexplainably topple over or dishes will slip out of even the most experienced servers' hands. No matter who is sitting at table ten, you just know something is going to happen.

I smiled my most winning smile at the two ladies. One of the women looked to be in her mid-thirties, with dark hair and eyes. She was well-dressed in a pair of slacks with a form-fitting shirt that made it clear she was in excellent shape, and a jacket that matched her sensibly-low heels. In short, she was dressed like Beckett in an episode of Castle, or any other female cop in a prime-time, murder-porn TV show.

The other looked to be in her mid-twenties, with long, wild sandy blonde hair that fell in waves past her shoulders. It looked like it had not been brushed in several days. She was wearing faded jeans and sneakers, and a faded black Realtree sweatshirt with cammo lettering.

In short, these women could not have appeared less likely to be dining together. But whatever. I'm not here to ask questions, right?

The well-dressed woman said she had eaten earlier and simply ordered water with a slight English accent. The younger woman ordered country-style steak, two orders of fried chicken, and two slices of Kentucky pie. I wondered how someone could possibly put away that much food , but hey… big bill, big tip. Who am I to question? Maybe she had a tapeworm.

I had just finished scrubbing the tea urns after promising my manager Tess that I would lock up. The women were the last two people other than myself in the building and I had already cleared the dishes and was waiting for them to pay and leave. I finished closing work in the kitchen and headed out the back door that lead to the dining area and around to the front of the building to check that the lights were off. I was about to round the corner into their section when I first caught wind of their conversation . I should have just delivered the bill and minded my own fucking business. But I've never been good at being sensible. I slipped silently into the next dining room area to listen as pieces of their conversation floated towards me.

"….. Can't kill him, he holds too much power…"

"Even the witches would not dare ."

"….Can't control the pack for much longer."

"Vampires have not had a council outside what the Vatican controls in centuries,"

What the fuck? Murder? Witches? Vampires in the Vatican?

Actually having been raised Catholic, that last part I could believe.

I was still hiding in the next dining room when they went silent. Could they hear me? Did they know I was back there? I crawled my way to the doorway that connected the two dining room, hoping to covertly peek around the corner. I prayed the damn ancient saloon-style double doors wouldn't squeak too much when I opened them. Then again, I wasn't exactly able crawl all that silently, either. The building is over 120 years old and has all the original flooring. It groans and squeaks with just about every movement. I cursed all the times I chose tacos over going to the gym as I gingerly tried to make my way to the doors.

When I got there, I decided not to risk trying to open the doors. Instead, I stuck my head under them only far enough to look under the booths to double check that the two ladies were still there. I briefly praised my own foresight in having already throughly swept and mopped the floor. Maybe Grandpa's half-eaten biscuits and gravy wouldn't end up in my hair.

Table ten was empty.

I was so shocked I went to stand up so quickly I forgot I was under the doors, and cracked my head. I rubbed the rising knot on my scalp and looked around, but there was no sign of the two women. I rushed around the restaurant seeing if maybe they had gone to use the restroom before paying their bill. No dice. I even checked the kitchen. Nothing.

I heaved a sigh. Great. Now not only am I the last one here, my last table was two crazy ladies who dined and dashed on me. Assholes.

I finished my last duties and stepped out the back door into the cool autumn evening. We were already busy when I arrived at work earlier, so I had to park clear down Railroad Avenue , and I had a fairly long walk in the dark ahead of me. The streetlights had gone out a while back but Glendale prides itself on being a "community" rather than an actual town. The result was nobody had gotten around to fixing the lights. The median age of the residents being somewhere between 75 and death, everyone was well inside and likely already asleep by the time dark fell. Fixing the streetlights wasn't on anyone's priority list.

I walked past the antique mall and shuddered at the eerie sight of porcelain dolls staring at me in the darkened window display. As I walked down Railroad the houses stopped and there was nothing but cornfield on either side of the little road. I always hate walking by myself simply because it always feels as if someone, something is out there. This night was no different and I tried to walk faster but I could not shake the feeling that I was being watched. Stalked.

When I finally reached my car my hands were clammy and shaking as I dug around my purse for my key fob. I heaved a sigh of relief when my hand found the fob, and went to pull it out when a black blur whizzed beside me.

Before I could blink, I was on my back in a small grassy patch in front of the cornfield, staring into the eyes of the English-accented well-dressed woman. I gasped for breath, the force of her take-down having knocked the wind out of me. I stared into her eyes, continuing to gasp for breath and not piss myself. Her eyes seemed different. Feral. They caught and reflected the moonlight the way animals' eyes do. She bared her teeth at me, revealing canine teeth that were… well, canine-like. It was like staring into the face of someone who had just stepped away from filming a scene for True Blood. I mentally counted down the weeks until Halloween. It seemed far too early to be attending a Halloween costume party.

It sounded like someone else's voice as I gasped out "wha..wha..what do you want?!"

I had hoped to sound defiant. Fearless. Instead, I sounded like an asthmatic mouse with an anxiety disorder. Fabulous.

"What did you hear?" Her voice sounded like a growl.

"Huh? N-n-nothing!" I squeaked.

"Bollocks. I can smell the lies on you. Now is not the time to bullshit. I have other ways of getting the truth from you." Shit. I'm gonna die.

The younger woman's face suddenly loomed over me. She spoke with a thick southern accent, but it wasn't local. "Just kill her and let's go before one of these blue hairs decides to talk a late-night stroll. We have to get going. This little bitch isn't going to fuck up us finding my father or talk shit to the wrong people. She's a loose end. Get rid of her."

I started to scream, hoping one of "those blue hairs" would actually be on a stroll, but the well-dressed woman quickly put her hand over my mouth. She looked up at the younger woman and sneered. "Bloodshed isn't necessary here. This one might be useful. If nothing else, she might know something." She looked down at me. " I suggest you stay quiet. I may be reasonable but my associate here would rip your throat out with her teeth and not think twice. She's rather rash, that one. So be a good girl, hmmm? Now, look at me."

I squeezed my eyes shut. I didn't want to look into those strange, feral eyes. She shook me hard.

"Look at me or I swear, they'll never find what's left of you. Genevieve? Perhaps you might emphasize my point? Let's let our little waitress know this is no idle threat."

My eyes were still glued shut when I heard what sounded like the growl of a very large animal. It was deeper and more menacing than any animal I had ever encountered. At the sound of it my eyes snapped open. The well-dressed woman smiled, revealing those horribly pointed teeth.

"Very good. Now, look at me.There's a good girl."

I stared into those fearsome, strange eyes and they seemed to start to glow. I felt myself become strangely calm. The glow of her eyes seemed to intensify, and I felt my body becoming heavy. I felt myself falling…falling. I was falling into blackness when I heard her faintly say "Good. Now we are going go for a bit of a ride….."

The world went black."

response:
When I came to, I was in the backseat of a car, my hands bound tightly behind me with what felt like zip ties. My head was pounding, and my mouth felt like I had been chewing on cotton balls. The car was moving at a steady pace, the hum of the engine and the faint sound of country music playing on the radio filling the silence. I could see the backs of the two women's heads; the well-dressed one was driving, and the younger one, Genevieve, was in the passenger seat.

I tried to stay still, not wanting to alert them that I was awake. I needed time to think, to process what the hell was happening. Vampires? Werewolves? Witches? It was insane, but the memory of those glowing, feral eyes and the deep, menacing growl was burned into my mind. I couldn't deny what I had seen, what I had heard.

The car turned onto a bumpy road, and I couldn't help but let out a small groan as my body was jostled. The women turned to look at me, their eyes reflecting the dim light from the dashboard.

"Ah, she's awake," the well-dressed woman said, her English accent clipped and cold. "Good. We have some questions for you, Kristin."

I swallowed hard, trying to find my voice. "What do you want from me?" I managed to ask, my voice barely above a whisper.

Genevieve turned in her seat to face me, her eyes wild and dangerous. "We want to know what you heard, who you've told, and what you know about our father," she growled.

"I-I didn't hear anything," I stammered, trying to remember exactly what I had overheard. "I don't know anything about your father. I was just waiting tables, I swear."

The well-dressed woman let out a sigh. "You're lying, Kristin. I can smell it on you. Let's not make this difficult. We need to find our father, and we think you might know something that can help us."

I shook my head, trying to clear the fog from my brain. "I don't know anything, I swear. I just overheard you talking about... about vampires and witches and stuff. I thought it was crazy, I didn't think it was real."

Genevieve let out a low growl, her eyes flashing in the darkness. "It's real, alright. And you're in the middle of it now, little waitress. You better start talking, or I swear, I'll rip your throat out."

I felt a cold sweat break out on my forehead, my heart pounding in my chest. I had to think, had to find a way out of this. I took a deep breath, trying to calm myself. "Okay, okay. I'll tell you what I heard. But you have to promise not to hurt me."

The well-dressed woman glanced at Genevieve, then back at me. "We promise not to hurt you, as long as you tell us the truth. Now, talk."

I took a deep breath and began to recount what I had overheard, trying to remember every detail. As I spoke, I could see the women exchanging glances, their expressions unreadable. When I finished, the well-dressed woman nodded, her eyes thoughtful.

"That's all I know, I swear," I said, my voice shaking. "Please, just let me go. I won't tell anyone, I promise."

Genevieve let out a snort. "You're not going anywhere, little waitress. You're involved now, whether you like it or not. We can't just let you go, not with what you know."

I felt a sinking feeling in my stomach, a sense of dread washing over me. I was in way over my head, and I had no idea how to get out of this. I had to find a way to escape, to get away from these... these creatures.

The car turned onto another bumpy road, and I could see the faint outline of a house in the distance. It was old and rundown, the kind of place you'd expect to see in a horror movie. The car pulled to a stop in front of the house, and the well-dressed woman turned to face me.

"Welcome to our temporary home, Kristin," she said, a cold smile on her lips. "You'll be staying with us for a while. We have some things to discuss, some plans to make. And you're going to help us, whether you like it or not."

I felt a chill run down my spine as I was led into the house, the sound of the door slamming shut behind me echoing in the darkness. I had no idea what was in store for me, but I knew one thing for sure: I was in deep, deep trouble. And I had to find a way out, before it was too late.

As the days turned into weeks, I found myself drawn deeper and deeper into the world of the supernatural. I learned that the well-dressed woman was named Victoria, and that she and Genevieve were sisters, part of a powerful werewolf pack that was on the brink of war with the vampires and witches. Their father, the alpha of the pack, had gone missing, and they believed that the vampires were behind his disappearance.

I was kept locked in a room in the old house, only allowed out under the watchful eye of Victoria or Genevieve. I was fed and cared for, but I was a prisoner, a pawn in their game. I was forced to listen to their conversations, to learn about their world and their plans. I was a witness to their rage, their fear, their desperation. And I was terrified.

But I was also fascinated. I couldn't deny the thrill that came with being a part of this hidden world, this secret society that existed just beneath the surface of everyday life. I found myself drawn to Victoria, to her strength and her power, to her fierce determination to protect her family and her pack. I found myself wanting to help her, to be a part of her world.

And so, I made a choice. I chose to embrace this new reality, to accept the existence of the supernatural and to do whatever I could to help Victoria and Genevieve find their father and prevent a war. I chose to become a part of their world, to leave behind my old life and step into the unknown.

It was a dangerous choice, a reckless choice. But it was my choice. And I was determined to see it through, no matter what the cost. Little did I know, the cost would be higher than I could have ever imagined. But there was no turning back now. I was in this, for better or for worse. And I was determined to survive, no matter what came my way.

As I sat in my room, the sound of howling wolves echoing in the distance, I knew that my life would never be the same. I was no longer just Kristin Renee Saunders, waitress at the Whistle Stop. I was a part of something bigger, something darker, something more dangerous than I could have ever imagined. And I was ready to face whatever came my way, ready to fight for my place in this new world.

Ready or not, here I come.

You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: No one I"ve come across in my travels know as to how the curse our world has been given was triggered. What I do know is that we are born with this sickness. This sickness is onset with prolonged sleep. Slowly but consistently it eats away at the mind of the individual leading to an ultimate state of insanity. The result is a mindless, caricature of a former life.


The sickness only occurs with humans, at the very least I"ve never seen an animal like them. They show no interest in animal life and occupy their time with the chaotic desire to kill and consume humans. They are especially effective at this. It must have been a lifetime ago since I had the pleasure of conversation with another.

Truth be told, it was a lifetime away.

I was imprisoned at the Fort Briggs; at least this was what the guard told me. I don"t remember what caused me to be imprisoned or anything beforehand-not sure why. In any event I awoke to a soldier looming over me. The surprise almost caused me to swiftly get to an upright position to greet my company but something in his eyes sent a chill to my heart as if the spear he was also carrying had already impaled my heart. But no, he only sat there resting against the cell, looking not so much at me as in me. It was like my soul was stripped naked and studied, his sunken glare penetrating its very depth.

"Well you"re not one of them, yet anyway. I"m no murderer but perhaps a fool. I couldn"t bring it upon myself to pierce your heart as you slept. I"ve seen the signs though. The cold sweats, the fear, and then nothing. Or at least for a few moments; they finally awake and it"s done. They just start killing and..."

His voice trailed off as he dropped his head. At this point I was upright but I hadn"t made any sudden movements. I have never met a distraught man but this seems like the situation.

But as if possessed he jumped up and whispered,

"They eat us! I-I"ve seen it!"

The dread and repulsion present in his voice was now gone and he returned to his initial position.

"We all knew that sleep causes it, and we fought it off for as long as we could. At last, not all of us had the same resolve. It was a recruit, a young lad who"ve never seen a battle or felt a woman"s warmth. He thought it a good notion to rest his eyes while on guard duty. When they found him, he attacked one of us in the most vicious manner I have ever seen. To think a boy could rip a grown man"s throat asunder! They were able to hack his head off but it wasn"t long before more and more of us started to drop. It"s when you go without sleep that you truly realize how precious the comfort of it is. And so, I"m all that"s left. My brothers-in-arms have all given in. Out of fear of them I protected myself in this cell, only to discover you. "

Afterwards he became quiet, as if he had been waiting endlessly to have someone to speak to. Assuming he was waiting for my retort to this I probed him on my location and such details.

"This is Fort Briggs; you are rather deep in the northern region of Iscariot. I couldn"t tell you why you are here but you have surely been blessed by Tali. There is no one left out there, just them."

Iscariot is the "land of blood" as it"s known. It has conquered several nations; it was thought that the Gods themselves had chosen for Iscariot to rule over all. Fort Briggs is a colossal structure that was created by the now vanished Titans. It occupies a small fissure between two steep highlands, making it the only plausible way to enter Iscariot land from the north. He referred to the Goddess Tali, which is an interesting note as Tali is not worshipped in Iscariot but in Ishla; a country mostly comprised of desert and chasms.

I was so occupied in my thoughts that I didn"t notice the sound of something approaching. The soldier was more alert and gestured for me to remain still and silent. The sound of iron boots grew steadily louder and louder as if it was ensnaring us, trapping us. And as gradually as it appeared, the steps began to drift off-but never did it go away. I never saw anyone but I did notice the soldier. It was if Death itself had gently brushed pass him, taking both his skin color and calm demeanor. I questioned the fear stricken man about what it was.

"Them."

It was clear that he was on the verge of insanity. I wouldn"t blame the poor soul. If he has indeed gone some stretched period without sleep then his state of mind has surely been warped. Seeing this it created an instinctive fear in me. I did not intend to wait in this cell for starvation or madness to overtake me. I made my way towards the cell door, but in a sudden moment the soldier had pointed his spear at me. Those cold, merciless eyes had returned but now with a glint of murderous intent.

"I empathize with you. I too have pondered the prospect of escape from this cell, to fight my way out of the Fort and so on and so forth. No one desires to experience the humility of being a caged animal but this is how it is. To leave this cell, this haven, would result only in a gruesome death."

This man has truly given in to fear and has lost hope of escaping our hell. Not deterred I made my intentions clear to him of me finding my own way out, with or without him.

"You will forgive me then. I have known you for a few moments but in those you have made me think you a sensible person. However, I won"t allow you to potentially jeopardize me! If they find you, then they"ll find me and I intend to go on with the rest of my days.

I"m sorry friend."

Before I had time to respond the soldier lunged his spear towards me. Perhaps Tali is watching after me as the spear struck just under my right arm and collided with the stone wall. The resulting jolt caused the soldier to drop the spear at which I tackled him. I had never been in a situation like this, where I had to fight for my life. We both desperately grasped for each other"s neck while rolling to and fro. I saw the veins rise in his face and his eyes bulge and turn bloodshot. I felt the heat of his skin against mine and the throbbing of his pulse.

I was going to die.

The soldier had obviously been trained to kill and was quite stronger than me and I gradually loosened my grip until he was on top of me and was I was near done for. It was during this I noticed his spear just within reach. With a stretch for life I snatched the weapon and struck him across the face. He stumbled over and grasped his bleeding ear. Not waiting for him to recover I attacked. It wasn"t so much intentional as my body just knew what it had to do. His iron armor covered most of his body so I gouged his face over and over. The squishy noise of each strike felt dark yet consoling and I continued. Blood and other stuff peppered over my face, while his was a red unidentifiable mass-and yet I continued.

Eventually I regained my composure and disgusted at myself I dropped the spear and sat against the opposing wall. It is one thing to hear about people being killed and dying but this was up close and personal. It was a rush at first but now a sober cold sensation remained. I forced myself not to think about what had just transpired. I needed to escape. After searching his body, I did not find a key to the padlock. A few hours went by as I tried to formulate another plan. It was during this I noticed the sound of water running. It grew louder near the rear wall, and upon closer inspection I noticed the water was running from beneath the stone floor. It was cracked in several sections and the thought of breaking open a hole could be possible with the spear. So I enveloped myself in this endeavor, quietly but slowly as not to draw the attention of whatever they are.

Over the course of what was likely several hours I was able to create a big enough hole to at the very least see what lied beneath. It seemed like a sewer of some sort but it was an escape. With the hole open, I only had to chip away at the sides and rather rapidly in contrast to my initial progress it grew to I was able to squeeze through. However the thought occurred to me that I may have to fight my way out and if so I could make better use of the corpse"s armor than he did. It wasn"t as heavy as I thought it would be but the added size required I expand the hole more.

I found myself now in a dark sewer like burrow. It was too dark to see what I was stepping in but I tried not to think about it nonetheless. Treading the thick liquid in full armor was not pleasant. Mounted in a corner was a torch which I carried with me as I cautiously made my way through the ever-curving tunnel. I had to hold the spear in one hand and its weight became more noticeable. Its tip was also twisted and rounded from it being used to break through the floor.

Eventually I came across a metal ladder to a manhole. Holding the torch in one hand, the spear in my mouth I climbed the ladder but found that the manhole was exceedingly heavy. Again, the spear was used to break it lose and I was able to crack it open and subsequently open to reveal a grey sky. I then remembered the northern region of Iscariot is consistently cold, with snow falling year-round.







Then I saw them."
[Requirements]:
1. The continuation should be consistent with the original story in terms of plot, character development, and tone.
2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.
3. Ensure the continuation is long enough to cover the necessary developments and messages.
response:
As I emerged from the manhole, the biting cold air of Iscariot's northern region hit me like a wall. The snow was falling in thick, heavy flakes, blanketing the desolate landscape in a pristine white shroud. I quickly scanned the area, my breath misting in the frigid air. The fort loomed behind me, its towering walls casting long, ominous shadows. The silence was deafening, broken only by the distant howl of the wind.

Then I saw them.

Figures moving in the distance, their forms distorted by the falling snow. They were not like any humans I had ever seen. Their movements were jerky, almost puppet-like, and they seemed to lurch rather than walk. The soldier's words echoed in my mind, "They eat us!" A shiver ran down my spine, and it wasn't from the cold.

I knew I had to move quickly and quietly. I couldn't stay out in the open, exposed and vulnerable. I spotted a crumbling structure nearby, perhaps an old guard post or storage shed. It looked abandoned, but it was better than nothing. I made a dash for it, sinking into the deep snow with each step. The metal armor clanked loudly, and I cursed under my breath, hoping the sound hadn't carried.

Reaching the structure, I pressed my back against the cold stone wall and listened. The wind howled, but there were no other sounds. I peeked around the corner, and to my relief, the figures were moving away, their interest drawn elsewhere. I slipped inside the building, grateful for the temporary shelter.

The interior was dark and damp, the air thick with the scent of decay. I found a corner to huddle in, trying to catch my breath and gather my thoughts. I needed a plan. I couldn't stay here forever, but I also couldn't risk running into those... things out there. I decided to wait until nightfall, hoping that under the cover of darkness, I could make my escape.

As I waited, I thought about the soldier. His fear, his desperation, and his eventual descent into madness. I wondered if that would be my fate too. How long could I stay awake before the sickness took me? I shook the thought away, focusing instead on survival. I had to find a way out of this forsaken land.

Night fell, and with it came an even deeper chill. I stepped out of the shelter, my heart pounding in my chest. The snow had stopped, and the moon cast an eerie glow over the landscape. I could see the figures more clearly now, their silhouettes stark against the white snow. They were everywhere, wandering aimlessly, like lost souls trapped in purgatory.

I moved cautiously, sticking to the shadows, my eyes never leaving the figures. I had no idea where I was going, only that I needed to get as far away from Fort Briggs as possible. The night was long, and each step felt like a gamble with death. But I pressed on, driven by the primal instinct to survive.

As dawn broke, I found myself at the edge of a dense forest. The trees were bare, their branches reaching out like skeletal fingers. It was a grim sight, but it offered cover, and that was all I needed. I ventured in, the crunch of snow under my feet echoing through the silent woods.

I walked for what felt like hours, the forest growing denser and darker. The trees seemed to close in around me, their branches intertwining overhead, blocking out the sky. I began to feel a sense of unease, a creeping dread that I was not alone. I stopped, listening. The forest was silent, too silent.

Suddenly, a figure dropped from the trees above, landing with a thud in front of me. It was one of them. Up close, it was even more horrifying. Its eyes were milky and vacant, its skin pale and stretched tight over its bones. It snarled, baring its teeth, and lunged at me.

I reacted on instinct, raising the spear and driving it through the creature's chest. It let out a guttural scream, thrashing wildly before finally going still. I stood there, panting, my heart racing. I had killed again. But this time, it was different. This time, it was one of them.

I pulled the spear free, my hands shaking. I knew I had to keep moving, but I was tired, so very tired. The adrenaline was wearing off, and the lack of sleep was catching up with me. I could feel the sickness gnawing at the edges of my mind, whispering for me to give in, to rest.

But I couldn't. Not yet. I had to find a way out, a way to safety. I had to keep fighting, keep moving. I had to stay awake.

With a deep breath, I pressed on, disappearing into the heart of the forest. The journey was far from over, but I was determined to see it through, no matter what horrors awaited me. I was alive, and that was all that mattered. For now.

instruction:
You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: Whatever you do, be aware of your surroundings. Be aware of everything. Capture every motion, whether you use your brain or you phone. Capture. Every. Single. Detail. You are in a new world, you are disoriented, you don't know where to go. Just use this guide, and you'll be fine.


I am here for some time, let's say about three months. I have already experienced that there are no humans, as far as I know. We are in a dystopia, and your main goal is to survive. That's why I requested you to capture everything, this can be proof later on that this world exists.

Also, there are just a few animals. Only some birds and not many other species. There are so called '*Crytids'.* These are the monsters of this planet, and to kill them you need to use your machete and stab in its eye. They are two feet high and their eyes are on top of their heads. It's easy visible because the head is just at the top of its body. But watch out, they are really fast, approximately they run at a speed of 18 miles per hour. The reason they can achieve such high speeds is because they run at all fours, excluding one weird limb at the back of them. It looks like a leg but is probably useless. They look just a slightly bit like a dog, so don't mistake a Crytid with a dog. Because we have Crytids, but no dogs.

The way to recognize those bastards is because your arms are going to tingle, which is an inevitable and undeniable feeling. Your surroundings will all suddenly go quiet. This is the most obvious sound a Crytid is near. So be aware of those things. Have your machete ready and prepare for a fight.

In this world there are a ton of Crytids, unfortunate for us. The first encounter with such a thing is often incredibly scary. But whenever you have fought with a couple of them, they will be easier to conquer and also easier to recognize when one of them is nearby.

Sorry, almost forgot to mention that they aim for your weak parts. In this case they aim for your legs. They do this so you can't walk and thus will be an easier target for them because you won't be bigger. When a Crytid is going to attack you, make sure to be fast with your feet. And of course your machete.

The goal why you are put into this world is a mystery for me either. I don't have a specific answer to a question so diverse. The most likely answer would be that you have been a naughty boy, a very naughty boy. Nah, jokes aside. This might've been a punishment because you were a bad guy in your previous world. Probably planet Earth, which was in my case.

However, I have no clue why I have been banned to this planet. Perhaps God thought it might be fun for me to give me a more challenging life, in which he sure accomplished. Although I am missing my friends and family at this point. I might know how to escape this world, but I am not sure.

Every. Single. Thing. Might not even be real. You simply don't know what is and what is not. But to escape this world, I need a partner. So if you have received this letter, you know what is waiting for you. My name is Blade. When we meet you can recognize me by my red baseball hat, and black protection gear. If you can't immediately see me, everywhere I go I put on the roof a tiny orange flag. I do this to know to which places I've been and which places are prohibited by me.

There are, nonetheless this is a really weird world, a couple of important buildings;

\- Head Building of Destruction. This used to be an office for guns. Whether it be the manufacture or testing of guns; you can name it all. It's a big building which is approx. 30 feet high and 25 feet wide. This building is easily recognizable by its American flag at the front side. (I have no idea why the American flag but whatever). The office also has a gun painted on the roof, so from the top view you can also see it. The building overall is like a giant box, with black painted walls from the outside. It has 6 feet high windows at the front side which gives you a clear view of what is inside. I recommend if you see the Head Building of Destruction that you go inside if the coast is clear and get yourself a better battle weapon. Like a semi-automatic weapon is good but a couple of knives are great, too. It's up to you. But keep this building in mind because there sure will be some weapons inside which can be optimal in a fight against Crytids.

\- Personal Supermarket. This is just a small 40 by 40 feet supermarket which offers the essential products to survive in this world. Like water, bread, rice et cetera. This is also good to check-out when you see it. The Personal Supermarket has its name in red letters in front of a green square. It has two lampposts at the side of it, in which the electricity has already ran out.

\- Crytid's Cave. Like the name already says, this is the cave of all the Crytids. Stay at all cost, away from it. If, however, just one Crytid notices you, they all come for you. The Crytid's cave is a really big cave on a huge hill. This hill lays in a desert and is easy noticeable from a pretty far distance. I had to run for my life one time, so I recommend you shouldn't go there.

\- Centre of Everything. This is the centre of this place, and is a hotspot for Crytids, so if you are going to this place, make sure you have your machete ready. Otherwise, don't go to this place if you are not ready to battle. I have been to here one time, and it's pretty impressive, so you'd be better off to stay away.

\- The Point. This is the place where you woke up. It's a meeting point for all the people that escaped this place and is easy visible because it has a sign which says; "This is where the end has started". I know this, because people have led me to it, but I couldn't go yet. This is an important place to meet someone, so keep that in mind.

Hopefully this guide helped you a bit, if you find this letter, meet me tomorrow at The Point. Right when the sun rises. You can recognize me by my red baseball hat and black protection gear. I'll wait for you.

Regards, Blade.



'Wow' I said, 'That was an intense guide and invitation to this world!'. I sighed, 'But I am really curious who this Blade guy is, he seems cool.' I said to myself. Right as I wanted to explore my surroundings a bit, my arm began tingling. I remember what Blade said; *The way to recognize those bastards is because your arms are going to tingle, which is an inevitable and undeniable feeling.* So I knew there was a Crytid lurking at me. I quickly searched for my machete, which was in my backpack next to me. I got it and silently waited for it. Within a split second it sprinted to me. I was scared but aimed for the eye, it aimed for my leg. I stabbed as hard as I could and I was unbelievably scared. But after one stab in its eye, it fell down on the ground, obviously dead. 'Pfew, that was close and scary', I said, 'but oh man, it felt so good.'

With my machete in my pocket and the disoriented feeling fading away, I started to explore my surroundings a bit, waiting for the sun to go under and rise again, so I could meet Blade."
[Requirements]:
1. The continuation should be consistent with the original story in terms of plot, character development, and tone.
2. Maintain coherence and logical progression in the storyline.
3. Ensure the continuation is long enough to cover the necessary developments and messages.
response:
As I ventured further into the desolate landscape, the adrenaline from my first encounter with a Crytid still coursed through my veins. The world was eerily quiet, save for the distant calls of the few birds that remained. The terrain was a mix of barren plains and scattered ruins, remnants of a civilization long gone. I kept my senses on high alert, scanning every shadow and listening for any sudden silence that might signal another Crytid nearby.

The sun began to set, casting an eerie glow over the landscape. I found a relatively safe spot to rest for the night, a small alcove in a crumbling wall that offered some protection. I didn't dare light a fire, not wanting to attract any unwanted attention. Instead, I huddled in my makeshift shelter, machete at my side, and tried to get some sleep.

The night was uneventful, but my dreams were filled with images of Crytids and the mysterious Blade. I woke up at the first light of dawn, my body aching from the hard ground but my mind clear and focused. Today was the day I would meet Blade, and hopefully, find some answers.

I made my way back to The Point, the place where I had woken up in this strange world. The sign was still there, its ominous message sending a shiver down my spine. I scanned the area, looking for a red baseball hat and black protection gear. At first, I saw nothing, but then, a figure emerged from behind a distant ruin, walking towards me with a confident stride.

As Blade approached, I could see the details of his gear. His black protective clothing was well-worn but sturdy, with various pockets and pouches filled with what looked like survival essentials. His red baseball hat was a stark contrast, a beacon of color in this otherwise drab world. He carried a machete similar to mine, but also had a semi-automatic weapon slung over his shoulder.

"You must be new here," Blade said as he reached me, a slight smirk on his face. "I'm Blade. You got my letter, I presume?"

I nodded, extending a hand. "Yeah, I did. Thanks for the guide. It saved my life yesterday. I'm Alex, by the way."

Blade shook my hand firmly. "Nice to meet you, Alex. You're the first person I've seen in months. We should stick together, increase our chances of survival."

I agreed, and we started to walk, Blade leading the way. He seemed to know the terrain well, avoiding areas he marked as dangerous with his small orange flags. As we walked, we exchanged stories. I told him about my first Crytid encounter, and he shared some of his own experiences.

"So, you mentioned you might know a way out of this world," I said, recalling his letter. "What's the plan?"

Blade glanced at me, his expression serious. "There's a rumor about a portal that appears in the Centre of Everything once every full moon. It's said to lead back to our world. But it's heavily guarded by Crytids. We'd need a solid plan and some serious firepower to get through."

I thought about the Head Building of Destruction. "We should go to that weapons building you mentioned. Stock up on whatever we can find."

Blade nodded. "Exactly what I was thinking. But first, we need to gather more intel. There are a few other survivors I've heard whispers about. If we can find them, convince them to join us, we'd have a better shot at making it out alive."

As we continued our journey, I felt a sense of purpose. This world was dangerous and unpredictable, but with Blade by my side, I felt like I had a fighting chance. We had a goal, a plan, and a glimmer of hope. And sometimes, that's all you need to keep moving forward.

Over the next few days, we scavenged for supplies, always on the lookout for other survivors. We encountered more Crytids, but with Blade's experience and my growing confidence, we managed to take them down. Each victory was a grim reminder of the world we were in, but also a testament to our determination to survive.

One day, as we approached the outskirts of what looked like a small town, Blade held up a hand, signaling me to stop. He pointed towards a small, barely visible orange flag fluttering from a rooftop. "I've been here before," he said. "There's a Personal Supermarket nearby. We should stock up on supplies."

We made our way to the supermarket, constantly scanning our surroundings. The supermarket was just as Blade had described, a small building with red letters on a green square. Inside, we found shelves still stocked with canned goods, water, and other essentials. We filled our backpacks, always keeping one eye on the door.

As we prepared to leave, I noticed a small, handwritten note tucked behind a cash register. I picked it up and read it aloud. "'If you're reading this, you're not alone. Meet us at the old radio tower at sunset. We have information to share.' It's signed 'The Remnants'."

Blade looked at me, a spark of hope in his eyes. "Looks like we're not the only ones looking for a way out. Let's find this radio tower."

With renewed determination, we set out, guided by the promise of allies and answers. The journey was treacherous, but the thought of meeting other survivors kept us going. As the sun began to set, we spotted the radio tower in the distance, a tall, lonely structure standing amidst the ruins.

As we approached, we saw a small group of people gathered at the base of the tower. They were armed and wary, but their faces lit up with relief and hope as they saw us. We were no longer alone in this fight. Together, we would find a way out of this world, or die trying.

instruction:
You should write a continuation of the following story.
[Story]: The look in each of their eyes was enough. It stopped me, as it would any other, in my tracks. The look of pure terror, tears streaming from their eyes. "no, please stop." "take whatever it is you want!" These were words I had never expected to hear, not even in the darkest of circumstances. Too little too late, I assume. After all, we are in this situation, regardless of what I grew to expect over the last few years.


The room, although covered in light from an old 1990's style ceiling fan, a lamp in the two corners on either side of a work desk that sit just across the room from a couch and loveseat set up, covered in clutter and the computer monitor dancing in bubbles and more light, had seemed dark. Perhaps it was in the air, for I had not come here with girl scout cookies and a young adorable smile. No. I had come here to get the truth out in the open finally.

A year of absolute terror and sadness, as I tracked down my mothers murderer. Following him in secret, lurking behind bushes and following behind his vehicle. The moment is finally here, and his secrets will be revealed.

I asked myself many times already how this man could be the monster he is and still lead a normal life, fathering three children and pretending to be this amazing husband. Grocery shopping, soccer games and cookouts. How in the hell did he manage his time so well, and continue doing what he does in the shadows of night.

Looking down, ignoring the family that are sat around me, bound to each of their own chairs I managed to collect from the dining room table. Five seats lay before me, forming a diamond around the empty chair in the center. This chair is taken though, we just sit in wait for the man of the house. The monster.

Maybe I am getting ahead of myself though. My name. well, this bit is irrelevant to my story, and the end isn't as important but by now you have to be wondering about the little things. Such as, my name, why I am sharing my story with you and who the hell I think I am to tell such a story in the first place. Like I said, I am getting ahead of myself.

Where was I? oh, yeah, my name. as irrelevant a piece it is, I'll allow you to call me Shadow. I am 19 years old and 2 years ago I found my mother. She had been brutally murdered and no, that Is not an understatement nor is it exaggerated because I am her child. She had been tortured for hours, her face had been swollen from the apparent beatings she suffered. Her stomach had been enlarged where the sick bastard had put the end of a fire exterminater hose into her mouth and hit the trigger. Her eyes were sank in, it had been apparent almost immediately that she had been crying in her last hours, and not because her favorite show was cancelled. The cuts all over her body, where she had been stripped and savagely handled and raped. The sight was ghastly, haunting me at every turn, whenever I found myself asleep or even simply blinking.

There was no real reason for what happened to her, other than the fact that she had been home and female. This is a fact I came to find after the first six months, studying the other murder/rapes that fit the same M/O.

The first clue I found was that they had all seemed to follow the sewage system, allowing me to track his next victim, where I learned his identity. My first instinct was to call the police, but by the time I found him, it had been to late. I barely saw his face as he drove past me, but the car screamed at me, for whatever reason. I wrote down his license plate number and using a friends father, I found out who it belonged to. Of course at this time, I had barely any faith that he was my guy, but sure enough.

I found his address and began following him. He was originally using the sewer to track attractive woman and within two weeks they would fall victim to him. Of course, I know you might be wondering why I did not stop him, turn him in or do anything but follow him. Truth is, I was angry, and I wanted others too suffer. Want him off this earth as bad as I had grown too.

Truth is, I wanted too understand him. Why is he doing these things? Why did he feel he had any right to take my mother from me? I lost my father to a drunk driver, hit and run. Imagine my surprise when I found that the drunk driver had been this asshole I spent so much time following. I practically lived in my own car, tracking the pricks every move.

It was impressive, after each day of work, he would crawl into the sewer at work and begin his hunt. Tracking down a new victim and after he found them, he would get this smile on his face. Bingo. That was my cue. Thirteen more woman after my mother, and guess where he is at the moment I stand at the center of his living room with his family. Victim number fourteen.

I realize at this point, I am no longer any better than him. If ever I was, that day was too long ago to even try to remember or even much think about it. Anyhow, again, I find myself going all over the place.

So here I stand, the center of attention, if it weren't for the blindfolds covering their eyes. Interesting enough, I got to learn a lot about these four as well, following their father, or husband. I made it a point to write down the point of tonight on the massive blackboard I stole from the school down the street.

The Truth Will Set You Free.

The fact of the matter, standing here, I had no idea how exactly the night before me would play out. Ignoring their cries was beginning to get further and further from impossible. "please let the kids go!" the mother of three screamed, "I will do whatever you want, just please. Please let them go."

"oh, sweetheart. If your husband does the right thing, nobody has to get hurt at all." I spoke softly, hoping that those words would be more than enough to calm her but as I feared. It had not been enough.

"why are you doing this!" she screamed, causing a further riot from the other three. Directly in front of the middle chair sat the wife, so that they could be face to face during the nights events. At his left side Sat his oldest child. A daughter of 16, they must have named under intoxication. Personal opinion aside though, Winter. At his right side, his 13 year old son, Benjamin and behind him, the child that he had allowed to grow so spoiled that he actually fought against my hooded figure, holding a gun to his face. Unloaded or not, an unintelligent choice. Victor.

"shut the Hell up!" I screamed, setting down the mobile plastic table for my recent collection of tools. "the next person to make a fuckin' sound will lose a finger!" the words, as empty a threat as it had been, were more than enough to calm them down a little.

My work here was almost done, as I sat my tools on the table and began separating them out on the table. Truth be told, I had no idea where this night was going to go and believe me, I also had no idea how far I was willing to go.

The truth had to be told though, these people deserved to know the truth about the monster they allowed to lead the family. It took me three months to discover enough about him to truly start my portfolio. His name threw me off the most, it was the name of a real family man, one without the kind of secrets this monster had. Kenny Churkle. What a fucking name.

The door slamming outside was the cue I waited for and within seconds, the lights were out, and I hid behind the door that when opened would find it smack in the center of all the delight I had in store. The door opened, and before he knew it I had myself wrapped around his throat and the paper towel over his mouth.

"the truth will set you free." I whispered as he slowly collapsed in my arms.

When he came too, he found himself the center of attention. His family around him, eyes no longer covered with the garments of clothes I used to form the blindfolds. The mask I was wearing sat beside my tools, which included a scalpel, buck knife, handsaw, wrench, hammer, nails and a few smaller knives and other odds and in things that within the next few hours might be used to inflict pain.

"Who the hell are you! What do you want? Why are you doing this?" he asked so quickly that my head began to spin. He sat there tied up, wearing his suit and tie so well. Working late, was his lie. He had to look the part I assume and this was his idea of doing so.

"I will ask the questions, but first I will give you one more chance to end it all right now." I said, kneeling in front of him so that we were face to face. His eyes lead to the soul and weirdly enough, there had somehow been a light, not even flickering. Fear consuming his body and paving way for tears, shakes and pure anxiety. "tell them where you were tonight, tell them the truth and I will begin to pack my things and make my way on out the door."

"wh-what the hell are you talking about? What truth!" he asked, the screams of his family got louder as it appeared they understood a wrong answer was not good. He was better off keeping his mouth shut, and if it hadn't been clear when he spoke the words, when I stood up, finding my hand wrapped around the handle of the hammer and swinging myself around and smacking his wife in the face with the brute blunt flat end of the tool, he found that lying, was not an option.

The blood rushed from the wound, where the hammer tore a decent hole into her left cheek. "No! leave them alone!" he screamed at me, Kenny, how dare he pretend to care. How dare he tell me what to do! Turning back to him, heavy breaths escape between clenched jaw grinding teeth. My eyes slit into narrow pathways that led straight to hell themselves.

"Do you feel in control of the situation, because you should. All it takes is a few simple sentences. You can start with, I moonlight as a…" I let the sentence hang between us as his wife came too, slowly lifting her head back up. Must have hurt like hell, because her grunts were awful sounding. The silence hung there for too long. "wow, you really care that much about keeping your secret, you will let them suffer this way?"

"I have no idea what you are talking about," he cried at me, sobbing, begging his God to end this and let his family just be free. "I will give you whatever you want, just please." He began to beg, and believe me, my skin began to crawl as his avoiding the truth was becoming more than I could take.

"LIAR!" I screamed and as I stood back up he began trying to shake free again, as he had tried first when he came to. "Fine, if you want to play it this way, Winter, I will allow you to come clean first. Show daddy here what revealing the truth really looks like!" I spat the words towards her father, lifting the hammer towards his face. "okay dear."

"leave them out of whatever this is, please. You can keep me, let them go." Kenny said, "just let them go!" he continued to try and shake free, as if that would change anything. In between work, stalking this monster and sleep, I found time to train in self-defense, karate and a couple other fighting techniques before tonight.

"so winter," I said, finding a smile across my face. "three months ago, a boy crawled through that window, things happened. Tell everyone here what happened, in explicit detail, if you tell the truth, I will slightly cut your right leg but if you lie, Victor over there, loses his ear."

"wh-what?" their mother stammered, her eyes were blood shot, and her head sitting back up it revealed her jaw must have been messed up or dislocated. "she-she nev-never had anyone ove-"

"his name is Daniel." Winter began, but was quickly cut off by her father. Telling her she doesn't have to play my sick games, that he would deal with me and that I was crazy.

"not playing the game is Not a goddamn option!" I screamed, slamming the hammer on the table, shaking the rest of my tools and shutting everyone up again. "I make the rules and for the love of god, if one more of you mother fuckers even tries to interrupt the process again, with anything other than the goddamn truth, I will fucking kill one of you." Not only did the words stop them even further than the hammer crashing into the table, but they scared the hell out of me. I never intended to actually commit a murder tonight but I found that not only was I willing to, but if need be, I was going to…

The knock on the door changed everything. Or did it?"

response:
The knock on the door echoed through the room, freezing everyone in place. The sudden interruption was a wildcard, a variable I hadn't accounted for. The family's eyes widened with a mix of hope and fear, while Kenny looked at me with a desperate plea in his eyes. I signaled for them to stay quiet, my heart pounding in my chest as I tried to maintain the upper hand.

I moved silently towards the door, my hand gripping the buck knife tightly. I could feel the tension in the room, the air thick with anticipation. The knock came again, more insistent this time. I positioned myself behind the door, ready to pounce on whoever was on the other side.

"Who is it?" I called out, my voice steady despite the adrenaline coursing through my veins.

"It's Officer Murphy," a stern voice replied. "We received a noise complaint. Everything alright in there?"

I looked back at the family, their eyes filled with a renewed sense of hope. I had to think fast. I couldn't let all my planning go to waste. I needed to buy some time.

"Everything's fine, Officer," I said, trying to mimic Kenny's voice. "Just had the TV on a bit too loud. Sorry about that. I'll keep it down."

There was a pause on the other side of the door. I could almost hear the officer's suspicion growing. "Alright, sir. But I'm going to need you to open the door. Just to be sure."

I looked back at Kenny, his face pale and sweaty. I made a quick decision. I moved towards him, knife still in hand, and cut the ropes binding him to the chair. I pulled him up, the knife pressed against his throat.

"Make a sound, and I'll end you right here," I whispered in his ear. He nodded, his body shaking with fear.

I moved us towards the door, using Kenny as a shield. I reached out and unlocked the door, pulling it open just a crack. The officer stood on the other side, his hand resting on his holster.

"See, Officer," I said, still mimicking Kenny's voice. "Everything's fine here."

The officer peered into the room, his eyes scanning the scene. I could see the moment he noticed the family tied up, the tools on the table. His hand moved to draw his gun, but I was quicker. I pulled Kenny back, slamming the door shut and locking it.

"Everyone, stay quiet," I hissed, pressing the knife against Kenny's throat. I could hear the officer on the other side of the door, calling for backup. I had to act fast.

I turned to the family, their faces a mix of fear and despair. "We're going to have to speed this up," I said, my voice cold. I pushed Kenny back into his chair, binding him again.

"Please," Kenny begged, his voice barely a whisper. "Please, don't hurt them."

I ignored him, turning to Winter. "Now, where were we?" I said, a cruel smile playing on my lips. "You were about to tell us about Daniel, weren't you?"

Winter looked at her father, then back at me. She took a deep breath, her voice shaking as she began to speak. "Daniel... he came over one night. We were drinking, and one thing led to another..."

As Winter spoke, I kept one ear on the door, listening for the sound of sirens. Time was running out, and I still didn't have the truth I came for. I needed to push harder, to break Kenny before it was too late.

The room was filled with a tense silence, broken only by Winter's soft voice and the distant sound of approaching sirens. The night was far from over, and I was determined to see it through, no matter the cost. The truth would set me free, and I wouldn't leave until I had it.

[Story]: Sightseeing. It is what I tell myself I am doing as I stand here year after year, viewing wistfully in the distance towards a collective nothingness. Upon a beach of sea-blue sand, dully reflecting the neverending haze surrounding this place, I stare into the ocean's mist, serving only to further cover everything in the same grey blanket of total blandness. The waters are calm and unmoving, carrying no wind, perfectly still as all else is here. The only movement that reminds me time is not yet frozen is the wavering deep-blue hue the water carries with itself near the shoreline, refracting the sand's gem-like azureness in a listless dance, until once again fading into a lifeless grey. It is all I can do to stare at this hesitant ripple of blue. It draws me in until the dreary atmosphere ever so slowly fades out of my consciousness; a welcome refuge for my tired eyes.


I am unsure when I first arrived at this place, it happened much like how one might forget a dream. Awaking with a moment of unfamiliarity, and a distant memory of a place that dives farther from your mind each second you try to grasp at it, until all that"s left is the memory that there was something that happened, some thought that you engaged with thoroughly, but remembered nevermore. I had tried to find a way to get away from here. I've ran along these sands many times in search of solidarity from this place, but alas, the beach seems infinite in every direction. Even the water itself holds no secrets of escape, for it violently steepens only a few meters from shore, and attempting to run away from the beach is equally futile, I simply appear right back at the ocean after walking only a short distance away, as if this cursed place is just a loop one cannot escape by effort alone.

So, I stand and stare. Time passes here at a dreadful pace, and I have lost hope of returning to my past life. Even if I somehow rid myself of this place, a mind can only take so much of this desolation before permanently adapting to it. The little solace I hold is writing these words into the sands, for this land's apathetic nature is kind enough to leave the sands unmoving for me to use as a canvas of words and thoughts. There is little else to describe here so this writing will end I suppose. One day I may add to my scriptures in these sands, but this place is making me tired. So, I'll let it take my thoughts to sleep, hoping to dream of a place that isn't here.



Writing Upon Blue Sands pt. 2, Sinking to Somber:

My mind skips upon my dead thoughts like these pebbles upon this familiar sea: plip, plop, plip are my thoughts, sinking into cold, lifeless insanity. My mind stands me along this beach once more, my body begging for the back and forth familiarity of flinging rocks towards the open nothingness—anything that isn't another nothing for my senses. I let the thoughts fall from my head and drag my body back to my scrawled words. I return to writing upon these blue sands to exorcise my mind from the silence and the blue.

I think I've found blue to be so… depressing. At first it was a welcome sight from the ocean's horrid blanket of eternal grey, but now my mind is in constant battle between the greys and the blues and the brights and the dulls and the same pattern of refracting light of the water's dance with the sand until my mind simply surrenders to a single muddled color of somber. These are the patterns and contrasts of the sole two colors in this world that I once thought would hold significant importance to my sanity, but now they serve only to constrain my sanity to yet another nothingness.

A mind cannot withstand absolute singularity of a concept for long before breaking; a single color or a single belief and ideal, a single order or a single life, a single one place of consciousness and decision-making that sits in eternal stillness for the extent of one's sanity—as afterwards, constraints on reality no longer matter to a broken mind. It is simply an environment that such a machine was not designed to survive in.

So, this world blesses me with living upon an eternal balance point between absolute singularity and necessary stimuli with its waveless sea, its stillborn breeze, and its shimmering azure sands that seep into your mind like drops of ink, leaving your thoughts stained forever blue. But again, I am blessed within this world to write within its sands and throw its stones back at itself in childish retaliation. The world could've let my writing disappear as my thoughts do, or let my stones skip only once instead of the occasional twice to my amusement. The world may steal my thoughts and feelings, forever lost within the depths of its sea, but it does allow solidarity from its environment in painfully short moments of self amusement through my actions here.

Unfortunately they are far in-between each other, and once again I am feeling my thoughts having been thoroughly soaked into these sands, wishing to take leave of my head and send me to my nothingness once again. So, I'll lay within these sands, staring at my nothing until my sanity tips too far from its balance point, and I will decide to skip stones again tomorrow or maybe continue my writings here another night. Whichever one my mind has felt is a greater necessity to its survival in this apathetic wasteland of blue sands and lifeless waters."
